description: After intense debate in the divided Council, Nikola Petrak is discreetly given access to sealed BCI communications. He discovers a trove of archived evidence of Council manipulation and BCI abuses. The Council urges caution, but Nikola faces a pivotal moral choice.

Nikola, recalling his loyalty to public service and Halden's warnings, decides to act: he prepares the archive for full release, consulting briefly with trusted past colleagues about the potential risks and impact on the city.

Nikola releases the unfiltered archive of BCI abuses to public citizen channels. The revelations spur shock and outrage, with crowds gathering at the mural and demanding immediate accountability from Council members.

Mass public assemblies at the mural force Council members to answer directly for systemic abuses. Open lotteries select interim citizen delegates. It is decided BCI will be kept only for minimal public safety tasks, while neighborhood-elected managers take over all other governance.

Council leadership—pushed by public pressure—announces the ceding of algorithmic authority. Oksana Lintz and Rada Miskovic formally recognize the new system of citizen councils, as morale rises and Stenograd transitions to open, participatory management.
